channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: How China Is Reacting to DeepSeek Upending the A.I. Race
item.description: Social media exploded in a celebration after the news that a Chinese start-up had made an artificial intelligence tool that was more efficient than any in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:description: The news that the Chinese start-up DeepSeek can build artificial intelligence models that are as good as OpenAI’s, and at a fraction of the cost, sent Silicon Valley into a panic.

item.title: How DeepSeek Went From Stock Trader to A.I. Star
item.description: The little-known artificial intelligence firm has emphasized research, even as it emerged as the brainchild of a hedge fund.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin, Paul Mozur and Alexandra Stevenson
item.category: Hangzhou High-Flyer AI Fundamental Research Co Ltd

item.title: Why DeepSeek Could Change What Silicon Valley Believe About A.I.
item.description: A new A.I. model, released by a scrappy Chinese upstart, has rocked Silicon Valley and upended several fundamental assumptions about A.I. progress.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Markets panicked after DeepSeek’s breakthrough on cost challenged the “bigger is better” narrative that has driven the A.I. arms race in recent years.

item.title: What is DeepSeek? And How Is It Upending A.I.?
item.description: How did a little-known Chinese start-up cause the markets and U.S. tech giants to quake? Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:description: DeepSeek is a Chinese start-up run by a quantitative stock trading firm called High-Flyer.

item.title: How DeepSeek Changed the A.I. Game
item.description: What is DeepSeek, and why did it cause the markets and U.S. tech giants to quake? Cade Metz, a technology reporter for The New York Times who writes about artificial intelligence, explains.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz, Claire Hogan and David Jouppi

item.title: Elon Musk’s X Partners With Visa to Provide Financial Services
item.description: The social media company said it would start a peer-to-peer payments service, moving to expand the app’s abilities.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:description: Elon Musk at the inauguration of President Trump at the U.S. Capitol building last week.

item.title: Citing ‘Shadow of Evil,’ Vatican Warns About the Risks of A.I.
item.description: A new document examines the opportunities and risks of artificial intelligence and calls for “moral and ethical considerations” to be enshrined in all of its applications.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis has repeatedly warned that the application of artificial intelligence should be grounded in ethical and moral considerations.

item.title: Chevron Wants to Tap Into A.I. Boom by Selling Electricity to Data Centers
item.description: The oil company plans to build natural gas power plants that will be directly connected to data centers used by technology companies for artificial intelligence and other services.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:description: “It’s a chance for us to help meet the moment and address this growing need for reliable and affordable power,” Mike Wirth, Chevron’s chief executive, said in an interview.

item.title: G.M. Has Plans Ready for Trump’s Canada and Mexico Tariffs
item.description: General Motors, the largest producer of cars in Mexico, won’t provide details on how it would react if President Trump imposes 25 percent tariffs from the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A General Motors plant in Spring Hill, Tenn.

item.title: In Seattle, a Meeting of 5,444 Mathematical Minds
item.description: Participants at this year’s Joint Mathematics Meetings explored everything from the role of A.I. to the hyperbolic design of a patchwork denim skirt.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: How Google Maps Plans to Handle the ‘Gulf of America’
item.description: Google said it would follow the Trump administration in renaming the Gulf of Mexico once the new name is updated in government sources.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant
item.media:description: President Trump signed an executive order on Jan. 20 to rename the Gulf of Mexico and switch the name of the tallest mountain in North America from Denali back to Mount McKinley.

item.title: How Does DeepSeek’s A.I. Chatbot Compare to ChatGPT and Other Competitors?
item.description: The chatbot from China appears to perform a number of tasks as well as its American competitors do, but it censors topics such as Tiananmen Square.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan
item.media:description: When asked to summarize the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, DeepSeek responded that the information was “beyond my current scope.”

item.title: Nvidia Reels After DeepSeek’s A.I. Breakthrough
item.description: The tech industry has had an insatiable appetite for Nvidia’s chips over the last two years. But the feast may be over sooner than many had expected.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nvidia’s chief executive, Jensen Huang, spoke about his company and A.I. at CES 2025 in Las Vegas earlier this month.

item.title: Oil Companies Embrace Trump, but Not ‘Drill, Baby, Drill’
item.description: Oil and gas executives welcomed President Trump’s early moves on energy policy, but many said they did not plan to increase production unless prices rose significantly.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:description: An oil platform on the Gulf of Mexico. Just how successful President Trump will be at bending energy markets toward fossil fuels will reveal itself over months and years.

item.title: E.V. Owners Don’t Pay Gas Taxes. So, Many States Are Charging Them Fees.
item.description: States are using higher registration fees for electric cars to make up for declining fuel taxes, but some are punitive, environmentalists say. A federal tax could be coming.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: An electric vehicle charging station in London, Ohio, which is among the states that charge the highest fees to battery-powered car owners.

item.title: Elon Musk, Video Game King? Well, Maybe Not.
item.description: Gaming is a big part of the billionaire’s public persona. But other players are questioning whether he has the time or the skill to be as accomplished as he claims.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan and Mike Isaac

item.title: How the New York Times Website Got Its URL
item.description: The Times wanted to go online in 1996 with nytimes.com. But the domain was already owned — by a Times reporter.
item.dc:creator: Megan DiTrolio

item.title: Trump’s Crypto Venture Divides the Industry He Aims to Support
item.description: The president’s promotion of a speculative digital coin left some crypto investors feeling blindsided, while others saw it as a gimmick that undermined the industry’s credibility.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: The surprise announcement that Mr. Trump was launching a new cryptocurrency came on social media while many crypto executives were attending a pre-inaugural ball.

item.title: Tom Green, Former Provocateur, Is Building Something New
item.description: A Y2K-era phenomenon most famous for his MTV prank show and surreal brand of comedy, Green pioneered ideas that thrive today.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam and Chris Maggio
item.media:credit: Chris Maggio for The New York Times

item.title: The Surveillance Tools That Could Power Trump’s Immigration Crackdown
item.description: Border enforcement agencies have spent billions assembling surveillance tools to track and find people. These could be critical in President Trump’s immigration agenda.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur, Aaron Krolik and David McCabe
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customs and Border Protection agents check the documents of migrants at the Paso Del Norte International Bridge in El Paso, Texas. The U.S. government has built up an arsenal of tech tools over the years.

item.title: TikTok Ban and Trump Executive Order Lead to Tech Company Dilemma
item.description: The federal law banning TikTok has revealed a major schism among American tech companies: Some are willing to flout the law — and some, including Apple and Google, are not.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari, Aaron Krolik and Tripp Mickle
item.media:description: The TikTok app stopped working over the weekend, when the U.S. ban took effect. But it came back on Sunday.

item.title: Meta to Increase Spending to $65 Billion This Year in A.I. Push
item.description: Much of the capital investment, a big jump from 2024, will fund expansion of Meta’s data centers, which provide the computing power needed by A.I. products and algorithms.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Meta’s Facebook data center in Eagle Mountain, Utah, last year.

item.title: Quantum TikTok + Memecoin Mania + Chris Hayes on the Attention Wars
item.description: “We are starting to see how Silicon Valley wants to do business during the Trump administration.”
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Rachel Dry, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Diane Wong
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Harshal Duddalwar/The New York Times; Photos: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times (Trump); Getty Images (coin)

item.title: ‘Eternal You’ and the Ethics of Using A.I. to ‘Talk’ to Dead Loved Ones
item.description: Examining what it means to make money by selling the bereaved on an illusion, the film feels like something of a warning.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: Instagram and Facebook Blocked and Hid Abortion Pill Providers’ Posts
item.description: Some posts related to obtaining abortion pills were recently hidden on Instagram and Facebook and some accounts were suspended, before being later restored.
item.dc:creator: Claire Cain Miller, Kate Conger and Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, attending the inauguration ceremony for President Trump. Instagram and Facebook are under scrutiny after Meta made changes to its speech policies.

item.title: In the TikTok Show ‘Famehungry,’ All the World’s an Audience
item.description: “Famehungry,” a show that’s performed simultaneously for in-person and online crowds, comes to New York in the wake of the app’s brief ban in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Annie Aguiar
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: The performance artist Louise Orwin decided to make a show about TikTok and its frenetic universe after meeting a 15-year-old with 30,000 followers.

item.title: Trump Issues Executive Order to Boost Cryptocurrency Industry
item.description: The order signaled that the president intends to promote an industry that faced scrutiny during the Biden administration — and that he has a personal stake in.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:description: President Trump at a Bitcoin conference in Nashville in July. Last week, he began selling a memecoin.

item.title: OpenAI Unveils New Agent Tool ‘Operator’
item.description: The new tool, called Operator, can shop for groceries or book a restaurant reservation. But it still needs help from humans.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:description: OpenAI’s newest tool is an A.I. agent called Operator.

item.title: A Test So Hard No AI System Can Pass It — Yet
item.description: The creators of a new test called “Humanity’s Last Exam” argue we may soon lose the ability to create tests hard enough for A.I. models.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose

item.title: How Chinese A.I. Start-Up DeepSeek Is Competing With OpenAI and Google
item.description: The company built a cheaper, competitive chatbot with fewer high-end computer chips than U.S. behemoths like Google and OpenAI, showing the limits of chip export control.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Meaghan Tobin

item.title: How Trump Decided to Pardon Silk Road Founder Ross Ulbricht
item.description: Libertarian and crypto allies of Ross Ulbricht, who was serving a life sentence for distributing drugs on his Silk Road website, leveraged President Trump’s desire for political support to secure his release.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: Members of the Libertarian Party chanting and demanding the release of Ross Ulbricht, the founder of Silk Road, during the party’s national convention in May.

item.title: Amazon Closes Operations in Quebec, Laying off 1,700 Workers
item.description: Unions had gained a foothold in one of the company’s warehouses in the province, though Amazon would not say if there was a connection.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Christinne Muschi/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Workers at Amazon’s warehouse in Laval, Quebec, voted to unionize last year.

item.title: Reddit Users Boycott X Links After Elon Musk’s Gesture at Inaugural Event
item.description: A boycott of links to Mr. Musk’s social media platform spread on Reddit this week, after he made a gesture that some likened to a Nazi salute. Others worried about censorship.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Some communities on Reddit were shunning content from the social media site X this week.

item.title: South Carolina Utility Wants to Sell Unfinished Nuclear Power Site
item.description: The utility, Santee Cooper, is trying to sell two nuclear reactors that it abandoned in 2017 as tech companies seek new sources of electricity for data centers.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kaye
item.category: South Carolina Public Service Authority (Santee Cooper)
item.media:description: The V.C. Summer power plant near Jenkinsville, S.C., in 2016. Construction on two new reactors was halted in 2017 because of delays and cost overruns.

item.title: Why You Might Suddenly Be Following Trump on Instagram and Facebook
item.description: Many Instagram and Facebook users say they are confused about why they are seeing posts from the president and vice president in their feeds. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Some Instagram and Facebook users have found themselves following the president and vice president in the social media apps even though they had not signed up to do so.
